speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is apologizing to Paris for not yet having spoken to Juliet about their marriage plans, explaining that Tybalt's death has left the household in mourning. He then abruptly ends the conversation, saying it's too late for Juliet to come down and that he is too tired to continue, effectively postponing the discussion.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet explains that unfortunate events (Tybalt's death) prevented him from discussing marriage with Juliet. He notes Juliet's deep affection for Tybalt and his own, then fatalistically comments 'we were born to die.' He says it's too late for Juliet to come down tonight, and politely adds that only the visitor's presence kept him from going to bed earlier. Paraphrase: Due to today's tragedy, I haven't spoken to Juliet about marriage. She loved Tybalt deeply, as did I - but death comes to us all. It's too late for her to join us now; I'd be asleep already if not for your visit.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is telling Lady Capulet that the recent death of Tybalt makes this a sorrowful time, not a suitable one for courtship. He politely ends the conversation and asks her to pass his regards to Juliet.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris acknowledges that the current period of grief (after Tybalt's death) is not appropriate for courtship. He bids Lady Capulet goodnight and asks her to give his regards to Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Capulet she will speak with Juliet in the morning about marrying Paris. She explains that Juliet is currently shut away in her room, overwhelmed by grief over Tybalt's death, and thus unavailable for conversation tonight.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: 'Mew'd up' means confined or shut away, like a bird in a cage; 'heaviness' refers to her deep grief or sorrow. Lady Capulet is saying Juliet is currently shut in her room, overwhelmed by sadness (over Tybalt's death), but she'll find out Juliet's feelings about marrying Paris in the morning.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is promising Paris that he will offer Juliet's hand in marriage, confidently asserting that she will obey his decision. He then instructs his wife to inform Juliet about the planned wedding this coming Wednesday, but he pauses to check what day it currently is.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet rashly promises Juliet's love to Paris, assuming she'll obey him completely. He tells his wife to inform Juliet about Paris's proposal and prepare for a Wednesday wedding, then pauses to check the current date.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is informing Lord Capulet that the current day is Monday. This detail is crucial because Capulet is about to propose that Paris marry Juliet in just a few days, on Thursday, setting a frantic pace for the tragic events to come.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris simply answers Capulet's question about the current day of the week. This brief response shows Paris's attentiveness and eagerness to move forward with the wedding plans.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is hastily arranging Juliet's marriage to Paris, settling on Thursday. He wants a small, quiet ceremony because Tybalt has just died; a large celebration would seem disrespectful to their slain kinsman. He asks Paris if he approves of the quick date and modest plans.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet abruptly changes the wedding date from Monday to Thursday, telling Paris that Juliet will marry him then. He asks if Paris approves of the quick timing and explains they'll have a small ceremony with only a few guests because Tybalt's recent death makes large celebrations inappropriate—it might seem they didn't care about their relative.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is eager to marry Juliet and wishes the wedding could happen immediately. He expresses this impatience to Lord Capulet, hoping to speed up their arranged marriage.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris expresses eagerness for the wedding, wishing Thursday would come immediately. 'Would that' is an archaic way of saying 'I wish that'.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells his wife to inform Juliet that her marriage to Paris is set for Thursday. He then calls for a servant to light his way to bed, noting how late it has become—so late it will soon be morning. This hasty decision, made without Juliet's consent, sets up the tragic conflict to follow.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells Paris to leave and confirms Thursday as the wedding day. He instructs his wife to prepare Juliet for the wedding before bedtime. 'Light to my chamber' means bring a candle/lamp to his room. 'Afore me' is an exclamation like 'upon my soul'. He notes how late it is, saying it will soon be considered early morning. Paraphrase: Go now - we'll have the wedding Thursday. Wife, tell Juliet to get ready before bed. Bring light to my room - it's so late it'll soon be early. Good night.
